questions.text: You have gone to a village for screening where people have diabetes and hypertension. What type of screening is done for family members of these patients who show up in large numbers?
questions.solution:
• High-risk screening targets individuals at increased risk due to family history, occupation, or exposure.
  • In this case, family members of diabetic and hypertensive patients are at a higher genetic and lifestyle risk of developing these conditions.
  • This approach optimizes resources by focusing on a subgroup with a greater probability of disease, improving early detection and intervention.

Types of Screening in Public Health

Screening programs are classified based on population coverage and purpose.

Type of Screening

Description

Example

Mass screening

Testing entire populations, regardless of risk.

Screening all adults in a village for hypertension.

High-risk screening

Targeting individuals with known risk factors.

Screening family members of diabetics for early detection.

Multiphasic screening

Conducting multiple tests in one session to detect various diseases.

Screening for diabetes, hypertension, and cholesterol simultaneously.

Anonymous screening

Testing where participants' identities remain unknown.

HIV screening in high-risk populations without recording names.

 

Multiphasic screening (Option A): Incorrect because this involves testing multiple diseases in one go, rather than focusing on a high-risk group.

 

Mass screening (Option B): Incorrect because mass screening includes everyone, not just high-risk individuals.

 

Anonymous screening (Option D): Incorrect because identity is not concealed in this scenario; screening is based on family history.

questions.text: Diabetic screening for the pregnant mother in India is done between:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 24-28 weeks:

  • Diabetic screening for pregnant mothers is typically done during the second trimester, specifically between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy. This screening is important to identify gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy and can pose risks to both the mother and the baby. GDM is characterized by elevated blood sugar levels that occur during pregnancy and usually resolves after childbirth.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 32-36 weeks: It is not the typical timeframe for diabetic screening in pregnancy. By this time, if GDM has not been identified earlier, it might be too late to implement effective interventions.

Option C - 18-24 weeks: It is relatively early in the pregnancy and not the standard time for diabetic screening. GDM usually becomes more evident as pregnancy progresses.

Option D - 14-18 weeks: It is also relatively early in the pregnancy and not the standard time for diabetic screening. GDM typically develops later in pregnancy due to changes in hormone levels and insulin resistance.

questions.text: The current approach for the initial screening of women for cervical cancer at a primary health center is-

choices.text: Visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution:

  • Visual inspection after the application of a 5% acetic acid solution, also known as VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid)
  • is a widely used and effective method for the initial screening of cervical cancer in resource-limited settings.

Visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA):

  • is a simple and cost-effective method that involves the application of 5% acetic acid to the cervix.
  • The acid causes any abnormal areas to turn white, which can be visually detected.
  • VIA is a suitable screening method in primary health centers as it does not require sophisticated equipment or extensive training.
  • If an abnormal area is detected, further diagnostic tests such as colposcopy and cervical biopsy may be recommended.

Colposcopy (Option B): Is not typically used as an initial screening method in primary health centers due to the need for specialized equipment and trained personnel.

Cervical biopsy (Option C): Is an invasive procedure and is not typically performed as part of the initial screening process.

High vaginal biopsy (Option D: Is not a specific screening method for cervical cancer and is not commonly used as an initial screening strategy.

questions.text: For assessing the viral load in a test sample, which test utilizes the provided graph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Real-time RT PCR

  • The above image shows the cycle threshold or Ct value of Real time RT PCR which is used to assess the viral genetic load.
  • In the graph above, the cycle number is on the x-axis and relative fluorescence is on the y-axis.

Real-Time RT PCR

  • CT value (cyclical threshold) - Inversely Proportional to virus load.
  • The CT or threshold cycle value is the cycle number at which the fluorescence generated within a reaction crosses the fluorescence threshold, a fluorescent signal significantly above the background fluorescence.
  • At the threshold cycle, a detectable amount of amplicon product has been generated during the early exponential phase of the reaction. The threshold cycle is inversely proportional to the original relative expression level of the gene of interest.

Antigen test (Option A): A rapid antigen test, is a rapid diagnostic test suitable for point-of-care testing that directly detects the presence or absence of an antigen.

CBNAAT (Option C): The cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) assay is a real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) cartridge-based assay for the simultaneous detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance from biological specimen samples within two hours.

TruNat (Option D): TrueNat is a comprehensive test for screening and confirming the COVID-19 virus in India.

questions.text: Which of the statements below is correct?

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

Explanation:

Positive Predictive Value (PPV):

  • It is the probability that individuals with a positive test result truly have the disease or condition of interest.
  • It indicates how well a test result predicts the presence of the disease.
  • Formula:

Negative Predictive Value (NPV):

  • It is the probability that individuals with a negative test result do not have the disease, reflecting the diagnostic power of a test to exclude disease correctly.
  • It indicates how well a negative test result predicts the absence of the disease.
  • Formula:

 

Incorrect Options:

In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive (Option A):

  • In low disease prevalence, a positive result with a highly sensitive test doesn't always mean a true positive.

Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease (Option B):

  • Sensitivity isn't influenced by disease prevalence; it measures a test's ability to identify individuals with the disease.

Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease (Option D):

  • Specificity isn't influenced by disease prevalence; it measures a test's ability to identify individuals without the disease.

questions.text: What factor is the external validity of a screening test associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Generalizability

Explanation:

External validity of a screening test is related to its generalizability, which determines if the test results can be applied to a broader population beyond the study sample.

 

Incorrect Options:

Stability (Option A): Stability refers to consistency over time.

Objectivity (Option B): Objectivity pertains to bias.

Repeatability (Option D): Repeatability concerns consistency within individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis
Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis

  • Screening immigrants for diseases like tuberculosis ensures the health of both immigrant and host populations and is an example of prospective screening.

Prescriptive Screening

Prospective Screening

  • Done for their own benefit.
  • Secondary level of prevention.
  • Early diagnosis.
  • Done for other's benefit.
  • The primary level of prevention.
  • Control/ prevention of disease.

E.g.

  • Screening neonates for neonatal hypothyroidism (Option B ruled out)
  • Deafness in children
  • Blood glucose testing for diabetes mellitus and gestational diabetes
  • Mammography for breast cancer
  • Pap smear for cervical cancer (Option A ruled out)
  • Visual acuity for refractive errors.
  • Urine sugar screening for diabetes (Option D ruled out)

E.g.

  • Screening of immigrants for diseases like TB and COVID (Option C)
  • HIV screening for blood donation
  • HIV screening in ANC cases
  • Health checkups for workers in the food industry.

questions.text: A healthy person got in contact with an infected case, and they have to separate him as he is sick now. This is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B- Isolation

Explanation:

  • Isolation separates individuals who are already ill and potentially infectious from others to prevent disease spread, occurring either in healthcare facilities or at home based on illness severity and resource availability.

Isolation

Quarantine

For people who are sick

For well people who may have been exposed to a communicable disease

Separates people who are sick from those who are not sick

Applies to people who may or may not become sick

Restricts movement of people with an infectious disease to stop the spread of the Illness

Restricts the movement of healthy people who may develop a disease after possible exposure to an infectious agent

Allows for appropriate treatment in a hospital type/setting

Requires people to stay in a designated location, e.g. their home. For a specified period of time

Requires appropriate personal protective equipment (ppe) for those coming into contact with the person who is sick

Requires active monitoring including taking temperature twice daily and checking for other symptoms

Requires proper infection control, sterilization and waste management

PPE not required for contact with people who are not ill

Absolute Quarantine (Option A): It separates and restricts the movement of individuals exposed to a contagious disease but not yet symptomatic to monitor for symptoms and prevent potential disease spread upon becoming infectious.

Interruption of transmission (Option C): Tactics to halt disease spread, including tracing, quarantine, and hygiene.

Serial interval (Option D): Time between primary and secondary case symptoms, revealing transmission patterns.

questions.text: Which factor has the greatest impact on positive predictive value?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Prevalence

Explanation:

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease it detects, i.e., PPV increases as the prevalence increases provided the sensitivity and specificity of the test remains unchanged over the course of time (since prevalence can be considered as the pre-test probability of a disease)

Example:

  • Total population of a town is 2000.
  • Prevalence of a disease at three different time periods are 10,20 and 30% based on a definitive investigation.
  • Sensitivity and specificity of a new test are 40% & 70% respectively

Since the sensitivity & specificity are going to be considered as constants throughout, the number of true positives and hence the positive predictive values will increase proportionately to the given prevalences over these three different time periods.

 

Sensitivity (Option A): Sensitivity impacts the true positive rate, not PPV.

Specificity (Option C): Specificity affects the true negative rate, not PPV.

Relative Risk (Option D): Relative risk does not affect PPV.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the time interval between points A and B in the flowchart depicting the natural progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Screening time

Explanation:

  • Screening time: Time from the earliest possible diagnosis point (A) to the critical diagnosis point (B).

 

Lead time:

  • Time gained by early detection of disease or time difference between the earliest possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis. (Option A ruled out)

Generation time (Option C): It refers to the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host. This option is incorrect.

Lag Time (Option D): Not shown in the image; refers to symptom development to diagnosis. Hence, this is incorrect option.

questions.text: Secondary prevention is most useful in the early detection and treatment of which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Cervical cancer

Explanation:

  • Secondary prevention involves early detection and prompt treatment to halt disease progression. It is most effective for cancers with a long preclinical phase and a reliable screening test. Cervical cancer fits these criteria - it has a well-defined precancerous stage (CIN), and screening via Pap smear or HPV testing can detect lesions early, allowing for effective intervention.
  • Pancreatic, ovarian, and glioblastoma cancers typically lack effective population-based screening methods and have short asymptomatic phases, making secondary prevention less useful.

Screening methods:

  • Pap smear – Cytological detection of abnormal cervical cells.
  • HPV DNA testing – Detects high-risk HPV strains.
  • Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (VIA) – Low-cost alternative in low-resource settings.

  • WHO recommendation: Screen women aged 30–49 years at least once, preferably every 3–5 years.
  • Early treatment of CIN significantly reduces invasive cervical cancer incidence.

Levels of Prevention in Cancer:

Level

Goal

Example in Cervical Cancer

Primary

Prevent onset

HPV vaccination

Secondary

Early detection & prompt treatment

Pap smear screening

Tertiary

Reduce complications & recurrence

Radiotherapy, chemotherapy for invasive CA

Pancreatic cancer (Option A): Usually diagnosed late due to lack of early symptoms and reliable screening tests; secondary prevention is limited.

Ovarian cancer (Option B): No cost-effective, sensitive population-level screening; early detection remains challenging.

Glioblastoma (Option C): Highly aggressive, short preclinical phase, and no screening method for asymptomatic individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Early Diagnosis and Treatment:

  • Early diagnosis and treatment are key for breast cancer prevention. Detecting it early through methods like mammography improves outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Specific Protection: Specific protection involves reducing risk factors, not early treatment.

Option C - Disability limitation: Disability limitation minimizes disease impact, not prevention.

Option D - Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation enhances life post-diagnosis, not prevention.

questions.text: If a patient tests positive for a disease, which of the following represents the probability of her actually having the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Positive predictive value (PPV):

  • PPV represents the probability that a person actually has the disease given a positive test result, considering sensitivity and disease prevalence.
  • PPV = True Postives / (True Positives + False Positives)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sensitivity: Identifies true positives but doesn't assess the probability of having the disease.

Option B - Specificity: Identifies true negatives but doesn't assess the probability of having the disease.

Option D - Negative predictive value: Assesses the probability of not having the disease given a negative test result, not a positive one.

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lead time:

  • Lead time is the duration between the first possible point of diagnosis (A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (B). It allows for early intervention and treatment, potentially improving health outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Screening Time: Refers to the period of screening before symptoms appear, not related to points A and B in disease flow.

Option C - Lag Time: Refers to the time between exposure to a risk factor and symptom manifestation, not specific to points A and B.

Option D - Generation Time: Time for disease-causing agent reproduction, not relevant to points A and B in disease flow.

questions.text: In a population of 1000 individuals, a screening test was conducted for DM (diabetes mellitus). It showed that 90 individuals tested positive for DM. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was conducted, and it showed that 100 individuals tested positive. Your task is to determine the sensitivity of the screening test.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 90/100:

  • Sensitivity measures how well a screening test identifies individuals with the disease (true positives).

  • In this case, out of 100 individuals with diabetes, the screening test correctly identified 90 (true positives).

Therefore, the sensitivity of the screening test is 90/100

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

choices.text: Sensitivity will decrease, and specificity will increase
Sensitivity will increase, and specificity will decrease

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sensitivity will decrease, and specificity will increase:

  • Sensitivity and specificity measure a test's performance.
  • Sensitivity: Identifies individuals with the condition (true positives).
  • Specificity: Identifies individuals without the condition (true negatives).
  • Conducting multiple tests can reduce false positives, increasing specificity.
  • Sensitivity may decrease while specificity increases with more tests in series.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sensitivity and specificity will Increase:

  • Wrong, as test performance isn't directly tied to the number of tests.

Option C - Sensitivity and specificity will decrease:

  • Incorrect, as multiple tests don't necessarily lower sensitivity and specificity.

Option D - Sensitivity will increase, and specificity will decrease:

  • Inaccurate; sensitivity usually doesn't rise while specificity drops with more tests.
